thread.title: Ashes 2015: Talking points from the Third Test in Edgbaston, day 3 | The
thread.title_full: Ashes 2015: Talking points from the Third Test in Edgbaston, day 3 | The Advertiser

author: JAI BEDNALL
title: Ashes 2015: Talking points from the Third Test in Edgbaston, day 3 | The
text:
ENGLAND seized back control of the Ashes series with an eight-wicket win in the third Test at Edgbaston.
Australia provided a bit more fight on day three but will head to Trent Bridge next week with a number of issues to resolve. These were the talking points on day three.
1. CHANGES FOR TRENT BRIDGE
ENG 2/102 "Four, five and six are a major problem." - Tubby on @CricketAus middle order. 19 to win. #Ashes #WWOS pic.twitter.com/z921DZfNiW
— Wide World of Sports (@WWOS9) July 31, 2015 IAN Healy and Mark Taylor have suggested some interesting changes to the Australian batting order for the fourth Ashes Test.
Discussing what the Aussies should do at selection ahead of next week’s match at Trent Bridge, both appeared to indicate that Adam Voges’s time was up.
Voges has scores of 31, 1, 25, 16 and 0 in the series. He’s not performing any worse than Michael Clarke and Mitch Marsh but is the most vulnerable because of his age — and unlike Clarke he’s not the captain. “There’s big chat Smith to four, Clarke to five, maybe Shaun Marsh in at three,” Healy said.
But Taylor disagreed. “No, I like Steve Smith at number three,” he said. “He’s missed out twice here in this Test match but last Test match he set up the game batting at number three. He made 200. He stays there. Maybe a Shaun Marsh in at number four.”
Australia is unlikely to make any changes to its bowling line-up, which performed well enough to restrict England to 281 in its first innings.
2. CATCHES WIN MATCHES
Joe Root catches Josh Hazlewood rocket 0:46 Play video
Cricket: England's Joe Root takes a spectular catch to dismiss Australia's Josh Hazlewood for 11.
Fox Sports 31 Jul 2015 Sport/Cricket/Ashes/Highlights IT wasn’t the difference in the final result but Joe Root and Michael Clarke highlighted the importance of holding catches on day three.
Root plucked a one-handed beauty at third slip to remove Josh Hazlewood for 11 after the tailender had helped push Australia’s lead past triple figures.
Clarke couldn’t match the effort during the English run chase, dropping Ian Bell at second slip when he was on 20. Bell finished the innings 65 not out.
http://t.co/NHz0jfW8ua 's page not found page is looking quite apt... Sorry, couldn't resist! #Ashes pic.twitter.com/ik8qqvD6nN
— Lord's Ground (@HomeOfCricket) July 31, 2015 3. WHERE WAS MITCH?
Mitchell Johnson was used at first change in the second innings. Source: AFP
SHANE Warne was critical of Michael Clarke’s decision to open the bowling with Mitchell Starc and Josh Hazlewood — and not Mitchell Johnson — in the second innings.
Defending just 121 runs, Johnson wasn’t introduced into the attack until the ninth over when England was already 1/47.
Clarke obviously wanted to bowl Johnson from the same end as Starc — whose first spell netted the wicket of Alastair Cook. But given Johnson’s success in the first innings, Warne believed he should have been thrown the ball first.
“I just think when you’re defending 121 runs and the way Mitchell Johnson has a spell on a few of the English batsmen ... just to set the tone first up,” Warne said. “You see what he did yesterday in his first over — he took two wickets in his first over. I just wonder if Michael Clarke’s missed a trick by not opening the bowling with him.”
4. ANDERSON OUT FOR TRENT BRIDGE
Was this the last time James Anderson touched the leather in the series? Source: AFP
ENGLAND pace ace James Anderson has been ruled out of the fourth Test in a major boost to Australia’s hopes of levelling the series at Trent Bridge.
Anderson badly strained his side while bowling late on day two and took no part in the match on day three.
“Obviously it’s going to be a big loss for them, but we’ve seen what Steven Finn can do,” Aussie batsman David Warner said. “Look what he did (on day two), produced a fantastic spell. We know what Woody (Mark Wood) is capable of as well, so they’ve got bowling stocks.
“For us, we’ve got to worry about scoring runs. What happens in their camp is in their camp.”
Stuart Broad tells Sky that Anderson will miss Trent Bridge but is very hopeful he'll be back for 5th #Ashes Test @surreycricket #Ashes2015
— CricketBadger (@cricket_badger) July 31, 2015 5. IAN HEALY’S MASTERCLASS
WATCH: Punter, @ShaneWarne & Ian Healy join @WardySkyCricket for a wicketkeeping masterclass: http://t.co/J8Wgbw2isZ pic.twitter.com/VGCfd9cP1c
— Sky Sports Cricket (@SkyCricket) July 31, 2015 ON a pretty miserable day for Australia it was left to former wicketkeeper Ian Healy to provide the highlights during a lunch break masterclass with Shane Warne and Ricky Ponting.
Healy discussed the finer points of keeping to a spinner like Warne during an excellent segment that was well received by some notable cricketers.
The @Iheals masterclass is absolutely fantastic.... #Ashes
— Michael Vaughan (@MichaelVaughan) July 31, 2015 Brilliant @Iheals masterclass was a joy to watch.Thorpe at Edgbaston just brilliant? Not enough of this stuff done for appreciation of craft
— Darren Berry (@ChuckBerry1969) July 31, 2015 @ChuckBerry1969 Quality viewing, especially for the wickys! #keepersclub
— Chris Hartley (@_chrishartley) July 31, 2015 Originally published as ‘Smith to four, Clarke to five, Marsh to three’
